./.title: Overview
./.body:
Coding & Cocktails Session 5:
Intro to Front-End Architecture 


Overview 
Basics of how to structure your websites and applications for more efficient and sustainable management.

project/.title: Project
project/.body:
Project 
Front-end architecture is the organization of code and project files. Though there can be customizations specific to a team, the goal of good front-end architecture is to provide an efficient workflow that is maintainable throughout the project’s life.
In this session, we will become familiar with best practices for front-end architecture by organizing a pack of assets in a way that will make it easy to maintain the website in a sustainable way.
While following along with the worksheet, type out the commands instead of doing a copy & paste (unless instructed to copy & paste) to avoid inadvertently using any incorrect characters.

project/part_0_verify_nodejs_is_installe.title: Part 0: Verify NodeJS is installed
project/part_0_verify_nodejs_is_installe.body:
Part 0: Verify NodeJS is installed 
In order to use NPM later in this lesson, you have to install NodeJS. (We won’t be writing a NodeJS application, but the two are essentially installed together.)

Open your terminal / command line



In Git Bash (windows) or iTerm2 (macs), type: node --version && npm --version
If you get version numbers, then NodeJS and NPM are already installed. Proceed to Part I.

project/part_i_manual_practice.html.title: Part I: Manual Practice
project/part_i_manual_practice.html.body:
Part I: Manual Practice 
First, let’s take a look at how to manually organize your project files.

Download the assets at http://bit.ly/2bVHBAi and unzip the file. 
Create a root directory named app in your CodingAndCocktails folder.


Let’s get organizing! Create the necessary folders and add your project files like in the following diagram.
   


Now open the index.html file in Google Chrome to preview your site. Oh no! Looks like the site is broken. We’re missing the styling and some images specifically. Our HTML page doesn’t know how we’ve organized our project so we’ll need to tell it where to find the files it needs.
   

Open index.html in SublimeText and search for all the lines starting with   to remove that block of code. Also remove the closing comment mark, --> at the end of the same lines.

In those same lines, you’ll see  DIR where the path of the files referenced should be. Replace DIR with the applicable file path. In the example below, that would be assets/css/main.css.

Before:

After:




Go through the rest of the index.html file and make the same necessary changes for the other lines beginning with   . Once done, save index.html and reload it in your browser.


Your site should now be working! We’ve organized all of your files AND index.html knows where they are located.

project/part_ii_scaffolding_with_yeoman..title: Part II: Scaffolding with Yeoman
project/part_ii_scaffolding_with_yeoman..body:
Part II: Scaffolding with Yeoman 
You just did a great job with manually applying good front-end architecture practices! There are also tools which will help you automate this process of scaffolding your app. The term ‘scaffolding’ refers to creating a predefined structure  for your app. Let’s go over using Yeoman, one such toolset. We’ll be installing the TodoMVC app.

project/part_1_create_a_project_folder.h.title: Part 1: Create a project folder
project/part_1_create_a_project_folder.h.body:
Part 1: Create a project folder 
When you’re starting from scratch, an empty project is simply an empty folder. You could do that visually (using your file explorer) but let’s do it in Git Bash (windows) or iTerm2 (macs).


Navigate to your CodingAndCocktails folder: cd /CodingAndCocktails



Make a new folder called mytodo: mkdir mytodo
Move into that new folder: cd mytodo

project/part_2_installyeoman.html.title: Part 2:  Install Yeoman
project/part_2_installyeoman.html.body:
Part 2:  Install Yeoman 
Yeoman is a tool for setting up your project structure which can be used throughout a variety of projects. You can run these commands from anywhere, since we’ll be installing Yeoman globally.

In Git Bash (windows) or iTerm2 (macs), type: npm install ­-g yo
You can confirm the installation by typing: yo --version

project/part_3_installa_generator.html.title: Part 3:  Install a generator
project/part_3_installa_generator.html.body:
Part 3:  Install a generator 
There are over 3500+ generators available for Yeoman. A generator is a plugin that can be used to scaffold your app. A plugin is software that complements and integrates into an existing application.

Let’s install the Fountain Webapp generator using in Git Bash (windows) or iTerm2 (macs), by typing: npm install -g generator-fountain-webapp
Run yo to see your generators.

project/part_4_configure_your_generator..title: Part 4: Configure your generator
project/part_4_configure_your_generator..body:
Part 4: Configure your generator 
There are custom options available for the fountain-webapp generator. Let’s make our configuration selections now.

Select the ‘Fountain Webapp’ option after running the yo command.


Make the selections in the following screenshot.

Once Yeoman is done, explore your directory structure using SublimeText or explorer to see what scaffolding has been created. You’ll notice that the structure is different than what we saw with the manual practice on this worksheet. This is a good example of two different application types that use two different types of directory structures.

project/part_5_preview_your_app.html.title: Part 5:  Preview your app
project/part_5_preview_your_app.html.body:
Part 5:  Preview your app 
Now, let’s run a NodeJS web server to preview our app.

In Git Bash (windows) or iTerm2 (macs), type: npm run serve
Go to localhost:3000 in your browser.

homework/.title: Homework
homework/.body:
Homework 
The more you practice, the better you’ll get.  Reinforce what you’ve learned tonight with the following tutorial.

homework/part_1_another_yeoman_tutorial..title: Part 1: Another Yeoman tutorial
homework/part_1_another_yeoman_tutorial..body:
Part 1: Another Yeoman tutorial 
Get some more practice! Follow along with the tutorial at http://bit.ly/2ciNXfC. You’ll be setting up a directory structure using Yeoman with another generator. The tutorial also introduces you to Grunt, a task runner, and Bower, a package manager.

homework/part_2_git.html.title: Part 2: Git
homework/part_2_git.html.body:
Part 2: Git 
Yeoman initializes a git repository for you in your source folder. Check git by running git status. You can also stage and commit your files to your own Github repository if you’d like more practice.

homework/part_3_advanced_topic_creating_.title: Part 3: Advanced Topic: Creating your own generators
homework/part_3_advanced_topic_creating_.body:
Part 3: Advanced Topic: Creating your own generators 
You can also create your own Yeoman generators for any custom projects you’re working on. Just follow along with the tutorial at http://yeoman.io/authoring/.

homework/part_4_advanced_topic_more_yeom.title: Part 4: Advanced Topic: More Yeoman
homework/part_4_advanced_topic_more_yeom.body:
Part 4: Advanced Topic: More Yeoman 
You can go further with Yeoman by configuring testing for your app, getting your app ready for production, or making your todos persistent with  TodoMVC . If you’d like to learn more, follow the tutorials at:
Step 6: Test with Karma and Jasmine
Step 7: Make TODOs Persistent with Local Storage
Step 8: Get Ready for Production
